Package edu.cornell.gdiac.audio

Interface AudioStream

public interface AudioStream
This class represents a streaming decoder for an audio asset. This class is used to read data from a sound asset, without necessarily playing. One use case is to provide input to a AudioDevice object. Another is to append additional music streams to a MusicQueue object. Decoder streams are read-forward. Each time you read data from them, they advance the getByteOffset() and getSampleOffset(). To start reading data from the beginning, you must call the reset() method. While there is some limited seek functionality, this should be done in conjunction with a read.

  • Method Details

    • getSource

      AudioSource getSource()
      Returns the AudioSource that generated this stream.
      Returns:
      the AudioSource that generated this stream.

    • getByteSize

      long getByteSize()
      Returns the total number of bytes in this stream. This value is different from getSampleSize() in that the number of bytes per audio frame is platform dependent. You should avoid using this value unless you know what you are doing.
      Returns:
      the total number of bytes in this stream.

    • getByteOffset

      long getByteOffset()
      Returns the current byte position in this stream. This value is moved forward anytime a read(byte[]) method is called. It is different from getSampleOffset() in that the number of bytes per audio frame is platform dependent. You should avoid using this value unless you know what you are doing.
      Returns:
      the total number of bytes in this stream.

    • getSampleSize

      long getSampleSize()
      Returns the total number of audio samples in this stream. This value is different from getByteSize() in that it is a platform-independent method of measuring the length of a stream. Keep in mind that non-mono streams will interleave audio streams across each of the channels.
      Returns:
      the total number of audio samples in this stream.

    • getSampleOffset

      long getSampleOffset()
      Returns the current audio sample in this stream. This value is moved forward anytime a read(byte[]) method is called. It is different from the value getByteSize() in that it is a platform-independent method of measuring the current position in the audio stream. Keep in mind that non-mono streams will interleave audio streams across each of the channels.
      Returns:
      the current audio samples in this stream.

    • read

      int read(byte[] buffer)
      Reads the next page of bytes into the given buffer. This method will attempt to read up to size of buffer bytes from the stream. However, because of limitations with audio decoders, the page size may not align with the size of this buffer. Therefore, you should always be prepared for less data to be read. This method differs from the other read(short[]) methods in that it reads raw bytes. These a platform specific implementation of the audio stream. You should avoid using this method unless you know what you are doing.
      Parameters:
      buffer - The buffer store the audio data
      Returns:
      the number of bytes read

    • read

      int read(short[] buffer)
      Reads the next page of audio samples into the given buffer. This method will attempt to read up to size of buffer short audio samples from the stream. This method differs from read(byte[]) in that it access the audio data in a platform-independent way. The audio sample values will be between Short.MIN_VALUE and Short.MAX_VALUE. For a non-mono audio source, this buffer will interleave audio samples channel by channel. The length of the provided buffer should have the same parity as the number of channels. Because of limitations with audio decoders, the page size may not align with the size of this buffer. Therefore, you should always be prepared for less data to be read.
      Parameters:
      buffer - The buffer store the audio data
      Returns:
      the number of audio samples read

    • read

      int read(float[] buffer)
      Reads the next page of audio samples into the given buffer. This method will attempt to read up to size of buffer short audio samples from the stream. This method differs from read(byte[]) in that it access the audio data in a platform-independent way. The audio sample values will be between -1 and 1. For a non-mono audio source, this buffer will interleave audio samples channel by channel. The length of the provided buffer should have the same parity as the number of channels. Because of limitations with audio decoders, the page size may not align with the size of this buffer. Therefore, you should always be prepared for less data to be read.
      Parameters:
      buffer - The buffer store the audio data
      Returns:
      the number of audio samples read

    • seek

      int seek(long pos, byte[] buffer)
      Seeks to the given byte position, reading the results into the provided buffer Provided the position sought is found, the data at that position will be written to the very beginning of the buffer. The value returned is the number of bytes written to buffer (including this position). So a value of 0 means that the seek failed. Because of how stream decoding works, it is impossible to move to a spot in the audio and stop. Reading has to occur at well-defined pages, and the position may be in the middle of a page. When we seek to a position, we have to be prepared to read the remainder of a page. This method differs from the other seek(long,short[]) methods in that it reads raw bytes. These a platform specific implementation of the audio stream. You should avoid using this method unless you know what you are doing.
      Parameters:
      pos - The position to seek to
      buffer - The buffer store the audio data
      Returns:
      the number of bytes read

    • seek

      int seek(long pos, short[] buffer)
      Seeks to the given audio sample, reading the results into the provided buffer Provided the position sought is found, the data at that position will be written to the very beginning of the buffer. The value returned is the number of audio samples written to buffer (including this position). So a value of 0 means that the seek failed. The audio sample values will be between Short.MIN_VALUE and Short.MAX_VALUE. Because of how stream decoding works, it is impossible to move to a spot in the audio and stop. Reading has to occur at well-defined pages, and the position may be in the middle of a page. When we seek to a position, we have to be prepared to read the remainder of a page. This method differs from the other seek(long,byte[]) methods in that it is platform independent. However, for non-mono audio the sample position should always correspond to the first audio sample in an audio frame. Picking a position for an alternate channel will affect interleaving when you wish to playback the data.
      Parameters:
      pos - The position to seek to
      buffer - The buffer store the audio data
      Returns:
      the number of audio samples read

    • seek

      int seek(long pos, float[] buffer)
      Seeks to the given audio sample, reading the results into the provided buffer Provided the position sought is found, the data at that position will be written to the very beginning of the buffer. The value returned is the number of audio samples written to buffer (including this position). So a value of 0 means that the seek failed. The audio sample values will be between -1 and 1. Because of how stream decoding works, it is impossible to move to a spot in the audio and stop. Reading has to occur at well-defined pages, and the position may be in the middle of a page. So when we seek to a position, we have to be prepared to read the remainder of a page. This method differs from the other seek(long,byte[]) methods in that it is platform independent. However, for non-mono audio the sample position should always correspond to the first audio sample in an audio frame. Picking a position for an alternate channel will affect interleaving when you wish to playback the data.
      Parameters:
      pos - The position to seek to
      buffer - The buffer store the audio data
      Returns:
      the number of audio samples read

    • reset

      void reset()
      Resets this audio stream rewinding it to the beginning. This differs from loop() in that it assumes the asset will not need to be streamed immediately, so it is safe to delete internal memory.

    • loop

      void loop()
      Resets this audio stream rewinding it to the beginning. This differs from reset() in that it assumes the asset will need to be streamed immediately, so it preserves any internal memory.
